clinical_study.brief_title: Driving Pressure and Postoperative Pulmonary Complications
clinical_study.official_title: Driving Pressure Limited Ventilation Decreases Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in One-Lung Ventilation: Randomized Controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to prove that driving pressure limited ventilation is superior in preventing postoperative pulmonary complications to existing protective ventilation.

primary_outcome.measure: The incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications
primary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 3 days after surgery
primary_outcome.description: Patient is regarded to have postoperative pulmonary complication when 4 or more positive variables exists according to Melbourne Group Scale.

secondary_outcome.measure: Partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood
The ratio of partial pressure arterial oxygen and fraction of inspired oxygen
secondary_outcome.description: The ratio will be obtained from the first arterial blood gas analysis on the first postoperative day.

arm_group.description: The control arm receives existing conventional protective ventilation with tidal volume of 6mL/kg of ideal body weight and positive end expiratory ventilation of 5cmH2O during one-lung ventilation
The intervention arm receives driving pressure limited ventilation during one-lung ventilation

intervention.description: Positive end expiratory pressure is adjusted to minimize driving pressure, plateau pressure minus end expiratory pressure from 2 to 10 cmH2O during one-lung ventilation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults greater than or equal to 19 years
- Patient who undergoes one-lung ventilation for thoracic surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status classification greater than or equal to 4
- Patient who is contraindicated with application of positive end expiratory pressure
- Patient who rejects being enrolled in the study
